caseStudy.content:
Year: 2025

What I did: UI/UX

Ongoing Project

OpenResource is my ongoing project aiming to find an answer to one question: Is there a better way to create community resource directories?

caseBlocks.textBlock:
Problem Solved?

I found that platforms like findhelp already exist, but in my opinion, they run the risk of feeling overly corporate and impersonal. When you build something that covers essentially everything everywhere, it makes it hard to connect with at a community level.

Local Ownership

From my past experience, I knew that most local governments and nonprofits often create and curate their own lists. So what if, instead of relying on a single platform, these organizations could have a simple, unified way to keep doing what they’re doing… just better?

Decentralization FTW

Establishing that one centralized platform feels too impersonal and that local organizations are creating their own directories meant shifting my focus to finding a solution to decentralizing information.

Simplification

A core principle of OpenResource (if not the core principle) is clarity, so I focused on stripping back the overwhelming amount of lists and replacing them with a clean search and filter flow. I coupled this with jargon free tags and consistent card layouts to make resources easy to scan.

Reflection

OpenResource has been my hardest project to scope, because it feels bigger than a single deliverable and could be executed in many different ways. So far, I’ve focused on making flows and systems that make clear and trustworthy directories which already feels like an improvement to the status quo. While in its current state it works as a single site, OpenResource is still in progress, with the goal to expand this out into a full design system that organizations can adapt to their own local directories.
